I want these fields in a survey form, as you can see from the older clunkier version:
def programmer_questionnaire_view(request):
    submitted = False
    if request.method == 'POST':
        form = ProgrammerSurveyForm(request.POST)
        if form.is_valid():
            data = form.cleaned_data
            ProgrammerResponse.objects.create(
                first_name=data['first_name'],
                last_name=data['last_name'],
                age=data['age'],
                years=data['years'],
                primary_language=data['primary_language'],
                languages=data['languages'],
                other_language=data['other_language'],
                algorithms=data['algorithms'],
                data_structures=data['data_structures'],
                challenges=data['challenges'],
                git=data['git'],
                ci_cd=data['ci_cd'],
                testing=data['testing'],
                open_source=data['open_source'],
                largest_project=data['largest_project'],
                agile=data['agile'],
                architecture=data['architecture'],
                concepts=data['concepts'],
                deployment=data['deployment'],
                platforms=data['platforms'],
                platform_other=data['platform_other'],
                interests=data['interests'],
                interests_other=data['interests_other'],
                learning=data['learning'],
            )
            submitted = True
    else:
        form = ProgrammerSurveyForm()
    return render(request, 'surveys/questionnaire_progexp.html', {
        'form': form,
        'submitted': submitted
    })

def qotd(request):
    # Get a random quote from the API
    try:
        resp = requests.get("https://api.quotable.io/random", timeout=3)
        quote = resp.json()
        quote_text = quote.get('content', "Keep going. Everything you need will come to you.")
        quote_author = quote.get('author', "Unknown")
    except Exception:
        quote_text = "Keep going. Everything you need will come to you."
        quote_author = "Unknown"
    return render(request, 'pages/home.html', {  # Change template if needed
        'quote_text': quote_text,
        'quote_author': quote_author,
    })

    echo "  local           Use .env.local  (sets DJANGO_ENV_FILE=.env.local)"

    echo "  build           Build containers        (docker compose build)"
    echo "  bash            Bash shell in web       (docker compose exec web bash)"

8. the user repeats until all images are grayed out (selected).

MeU
A dedicated host to provide categorized (bloggish) posts to invited friends.  This is a “look into my mind” sort of thing. It goes one way -- from me to you (hence the name).
Friends could be authorized to create their own MeU stack (and I could then be invited to it).
The inspiration for this is the failure of both Substack and Wordpress to allow remote posting and dedicated posting.

Components
The basic “post”
I have in mind some sort of JSON object with TITLE, CATEGORY, BODY.  All this could be displayed (via Javascript?) on a browser (HTML).
The Server
The server accepts posts and stores them for viewing.
The server handles login/authentication and keeps track of interactions (posts read, etc.)
The server provides a high-level view of the posts and categories in a tree format (“All” being the root).
The Viewer. This is the app that allows people to view posts and select categories to view (and be informed of additions to).
The Writer. This is the app (or superset of Viewer?) that allows the owner (me) to create new posts and new categories (and, perhaps, hide/archive both?)

please write ad copy for: Chapter One
Xiomara (‘syo-MA-ra’)
	I was in the kitchen, reading the letter when the knock came on my door. I got up and went into the front room. I ignored the kid sitting quietly in the corner.
	There was a buff, blond man with blue eyes standing on the steps. When he saw me, he said, “Dolores Hernandez?”
	I shook my head, “She was my aunt.”
	“Was?” the man said, his eyes widening. “I was told --”
	“She’s been gone for ten days,” I told him. Ten days, four hours, and… thirty-five minutes. Tia.
	The man looked disappointed. “Can I come in?”
	I cocked my head to the side. Then I shook it. He sighed and pulled out his badge. “This is official police business.”
	I’d figured that. No way a white guy comes into the neighborhood without a good reason. And the killings two blocks over ten days ago were a really good reason. The news said it was gangs.
	I could argue with him, demand he get a warrant but… I shrugged and waved him to a seat at the front table.  I went around and sat behind it. There was a deck of Tarot cards on my left side. Tia’s cards.  They were pristine. The bullet hadn’t struck them. No, the stray bullet had entered her just above the sternum, passed through to the far side but not before it nicked the artery and she bled out.  The card on the table when they found her was Death, of course.
	The cop sat.  He glanced over to the girl in the corner. “Can we talk alone?”
	My eyes widened. Didn’t he know not to…? The girl stood up and walked out of the room.  She avoided the kitchen, walked to the bedroom, to the lounge, and then slammed the bathroom door shut.
